Literature Review: Smart contracts have emerged as a pivotal technology within the realm of decentralized finance (DeFi), offering a new paradigm for automating and securing financial transactions without the need for intermediaries. This literature review aims to provide a comprehensive overview of the mechanics, benefits, and limitations of smart contracts, as well as their prominent applications in DeFi. Mechanics of Smart Contracts Smart contracts are self-executing contracts with the terms of the agreement directly written into lines of code. They operate on blockchain technology, ensuring transparency, immutability, and decentralization. The concept was first introduced by Nick Szabo in 1994, who envisioned a computerized transaction protocol that executes the terms of a contract (Szabo, 1997). Ethereum, launched in 2015, has become the leading platform for deploying smart contracts due to its robust programming capabilities and Turing-complete language (Buterin, 2013). Benefits of Smart Contracts One of the primary benefits of smart contracts is their ability to overcome commitment problems. Traditional contracts rely on trust and third-party enforcement, which can be costly and time-consuming. Smart contracts, by contrast, automatically enforce the terms of the agreement once the conditions are met, reducing the risk of default and fraud (Bartoletti & Pompianu, 2017). This feature is particularly valuable in DeFi, where trustless and automated systems are essential. Another significant advantage is the reduction of transaction costs. By eliminating intermediaries, smart contracts can significantly lower the fees associated with financial transactions. This cost efficiency is crucial for the widespread adoption of DeFi applications, making them accessible to a broader audience (Swan, 2015). Limitations of Smart Contracts Despite their numerous benefits, smart contracts face several limitations. One major challenge is the difficulty in accessing information external to the blockchain. Smart contracts are inherently isolated from the outside world, which can limit their functionality. Oracles, third-party services that provide external data to smart contracts, have been developed to address this issue, but they introduce new points of failure and potential security risks (Christidis & Devetsikiotis, 2016). Another limitation is the integration of smart contract code with traditional legal enforcement. While smart contracts can automate the execution of agreements, they do not replace the need for legal frameworks. Disputes arising from smart contract failures or bugs may still require resolution through traditional legal channels, which can be complex and time-consuming (Grigg, 2016). The absence of a trusted intermediary also inflates implementation costs for blockchain applications. Developing and maintaining smart contracts requires specialized expertise, and the lack of standardized practices can lead to higher development and operational costs (Bartoletti & Pompianu, 2017). Prominent Applications in DeFi Token Issuance Token issuance, including initial coin offerings (ICOs) and non-fungible tokens (NFTs), is one of the most prominent applications of smart contracts in DeFi. ICOs allow projects to raise funds by issuing digital tokens, which can be used for various purposes, such as accessing platform features or participating in governance. NFTs, on the other hand, represent unique digital assets, such as artwork or collectibles, and have gained significant attention in recent years (Eyal et al., 2018). Decentralized Exchanges (DEXs) Decentralized exchanges (DEXs) are another critical application of smart contracts. Unlike centralized exchanges, DEXs do not hold users' funds, reducing the risk of theft and fraud. Smart contracts facilitate the trading process by automatically matching buy and sell orders and executing trades. Examples of popular DEXs include Uniswap and SushiSwap, which use automated market makers (AMMs) to provide liquidity (Zhang et al., 2020). Protocols for Loanable Funds (PLFs) Protocols for loanable funds (PLFs) enable users to lend and borrow digital assets without the need for a central authority. Platforms like Aave and Compound use smart contracts to manage lending pools and ensure that borrowers receive funds while lenders earn interest. These protocols have revolutionized the lending and borrowing landscape in DeFi, providing greater accessibility and flexibility compared to traditional financial systems (Adams et al., 2019). Conclusion In conclusion, smart contracts play a crucial role in the development and growth of decentralized finance. Their ability to automate and secure financial transactions offers significant benefits, including overcoming commitment problems and reducing transaction costs. However, challenges such as the difficulty in accessing external information and integrating with traditional legal frameworks must be addressed to fully realize the potential of smart contracts. Despite these limitations, the prominence of smart contracts in DeFi applications, such as token issuance, decentralized exchanges, and protocols for loanable funds, underscores their importance in shaping the future of finance.
